history.content:
But why? Physics 7B is a requirement for both majors anyways, might as well take it. If you're going from Physics to EECS, you're probably interested in device physics, the part of EECS that is extremely physics heavy? Unless of course you've had a complete 180 change in interest. Device physics is mostly quantum mechanics, which I assume is interesting to you?

But 61A is completely useless for most EE, especially device physics, so I wouldn't rush it. 7B is more or less a keystone class, so I would take it ASAP because it opens up EE 130 and related classes. EE 16A is also useful. 

In summary, I would do 16A and 7B ASAP. 61A is just a really pesky requirement that needs to be done sooner or later.

In summary, I would do 16A and 7B ASAP. 61A is just a really pesky requirement that needs to be done sooner or later.

children.subject: also just note that everyone eventually gets into 61a regardless of waitlist position, so the lower waitlist position from doing the swap from 7b to 61a isn't too big of a deal. just keep in mind that you will need to get into 61a before the early drop deadline.

history.content: I’m an incoming first year Engineering Physics major looking to transfer to EECS. Currently, I’m officially enrolled in 8 units, but waitlisted for 8 units. I’m 155/211 on the CS 61A waitlist and 162/182 on the EE 16A waitlist. Since you have to be officially enrolled in 12 units to be considered a full time student, the financial aid department cannot disperse my loans. I was considering dropping CS 61A, adding Physics 7B (which has an early drop period), and swapping Physics 7B with CS 61A (I think the swap feature only drops you out of physics 7B until you can get into CS 61A). I would have a lower waitlist position. Can anyone provide any feedback on the situation?
history.subject: Waitlists and Financial Aid
